name: Fortix
description: Can you reclaim your ancestors’ land? Evil forces have taken over the once fertile land of Fortiana. You are the only one who can storm the castles and claw it back from the hordes of dragons. Experience a new type of strategy and arcade game. Fence off parts of the battlefield to corner your enemies.

reviews.review_text: Fortix  Rating : 7/10  Great casual game where you have to steal land by drawing lines from the edges. Makes you play 'just one more round'. Not that long, but fortunately there is ... Fortix 2 which is even prettier \o/

Fortix is a fun casual game. Use your mouse or keyboard and draw a path to cover up the map. Within your box you can kill dragons/bats and take down towers. Or you can collect arms within your drawn box to activate catapults to take down the towers. This game is super simple, but can get extremely difficult if you play on the impossible difficulty level. Worth a play, especially since it can easily be found for a cheap price. Definitely worth the time spent and I recommend if you like these types of games.

This game has a special place in the history of Steam, being the cheapest game available. It has also special place on SteamGifts and in my heart!  The gameplay is simple but surprisingly addictive. You are a knight, tasked to capture enemy forts on a map. You conquer land and anything placed on it simply by drawing a closed line around it, but there be dragons and enemy towers out there to get you. As long as you don't leave the borderline, you're safe though - until time runs out!  You owe it it to yourself to try hard and earn the right to play Fortix!  For what it's worth, it's fun!  Once achievements are at 100% completion however, which isn't extremely hard, you may not feel much incentive to play it further, especially if you own Fortix 2. Unless you are into leaderboard and want to beat me :) Make no mistake, though - it is actually challenging to earn a really high score. Maps have a time limit, so this is not a matter of simple grinding for more score.

At first I thought this game was some boring strategy game, or something along those lines (Let's face it. I'm a pessimist if a game is so cheap) but, well. A friend ended up gifting it to me, and I thought 'What the hell, let's see what it's like.'  I was pretty impressed. The game is hard to describe. It's like those old cell phone games where you control a curser, and have to make squares, and dodge random enemy things.  That being said, it's not for everyone, and a lot of people probably don't even remember before smartphones were around.  In short, it's a short, sweet, and simple game that appeals to me, and brings back nostalgia from back when I was a little kid with a tiny Sony Ericsson phone the size of a matchbox playing a game EXACTLY like this whilst waiting for the train.
Fun little game, definitely worth picking up! Nothing groundbreaking, but an enjoyable monster and tower hunt nonetheless.

A fleeting joy, but a joy nonetheless, is the best way to describe Fortix, which seems to be the combination-lovechild of an beginner's art project and beginner's programming project. While the art is interesting enough and carries what it needs to carry, you aren't going to be entranced, and the gameplay, while a bit repetitive, offers enough challenge to keep you on board for long enough to at least finish the game's achievements and receive the three offered card drops. The game offers two control schemes, keyboard or mouse, each with it's own advantages, which is an interesting and not-often-seen twist. The game offers standard option controls including windowed mode (always a plus) and the ability to mute the in-game music, which you will most likely be doing after it loops the third time. The gameplay is difficult enough to match each mode of play from easiest to hardest, with the hardest being worthy of the title. The game offers bonuses to be roped-off and captured in order to gain short-lasting special abilities such as a temporary speed boost, temporary halting of cannon fire, or the killing off of one of the infuriating dragons. The level designs vary and offer up a challenge as you gain access to higher levels. Be careful not to lose all of your lives, though! In levels with multiple castles to capture you have to restart from the first castle in that level if you run out of chances. For the price, I recommend picking up the game, for the trading cards and easier-than-usual achievements. While you won't be returning again and again as if the game is a nasty habit, it is highly worth being a quick guilty casual-gaming guilty pleasure.

I like this game. I also hate this game. But overall I like it. It does not necessarily take long to finish the levels. But if you want to spend more time you just go and beat the impossible difficulty. Achievements keep up the motivation.  Fortix may be described as a capture-the-map game in which the player has to capture certain areas of the map. This is done by venturing into the uncaptured map and basically fencing off a part of the terrain. Once both ends of the fence are connected to your baseline (initially surrounding the playing field) you claim the area inside. Movement is restricted to vertical and horizontal and fencing-off may be interrupted by a number of hazards of increasing difficulty (and annoyance ;) ).  If you, for whatever reason, remember the Game Boy game Qix you know the basic mechanics of Fortix. And if you enjoyed the former you will probably enjoy the latter, like I do.  What really annoyed me on the harder difficulty was that I couldn't always clearly determine whether I had started fencing off. Since part of the fence to-be-build is hidden under the player I often stepped of the baselline and got attacked without ever realizing the danger I had put myself in. Keeping enemy reactions in sight is hard when you are concentrating on inching by some tower fearing you will miss the baseline again and die. I sort of like the way you are stopped when you run into a corner but I'd much rather prefer a more direct control over when to step off the baseline. Fortix 2 has running which incidentally keeps you on the baseline - both by holding CTRL - a technique similar to what I have in mind. I'd like to have a key like SHIFT that I have to hold to be able to step off the baseline, also canceling the stopping technique. I could also imagine releasing SHIFT would result in the player returning to the closest point on the baseline. Although I understand that not having that return mechanism may be a deliberate decision in order to keep the overall difficulty of the game at a decent level. At times I thought it might be useful to have a key for making the player backtrack on the current fence - a move almost impossible to make after taking the first corner.  As I said before, I recommend this game as I do its sequel which I will continue to be furious with now.

At this point, the only thing you need to know about Fortix 1 is not to bother with it. Though it might seem trivial to complain when it only costs a dollar, the fact of the matter remains that with the release of Fortix 2 (which includes all of 1's levels) the original has been made completely obsolete and redundant.  Not that it was particularly worthwhile to begin with. With only a dozen or so strongholds to defeat, most of which comprise but a single level, Fortix is over before it feels like it's even started. The different difficulty settings do nothing to create replay value, only increasing the speed of enemies and lowering the generous amount of extra lives you receive, as the game is very easy even set on impossible.  In short, even having gotten it for free, I feel cheated to have wasted my time playing Fortix. The level designs are terribly dull and the presentation so basic and repetitive that the it amounts to being little more than a glorified flash game or demo. Save your dollar, or better yet find it a friend and get Fortix 2 instead. It provides the better experience through and through, and although I think the core gameplay of Fortix is rather enjoyable itself, this is simply an extremely poor representation of it that serves no purpose but to take up space in your Steam library.
